captions.text:
Hockenheim in the last week of
October, is gray and cold.

But none of that matters when
you've got a 591 horsepower
SLS GT to play with.

The SLS GT is, I suppose
for want of a better
phrase, an SLS plus.

If ever a car didn't need
more power it was SLS.

But we've gone from 570
to 591 horsepower.

We're at Hockenheim,
where there's
plenty of stuff to hit.

Despite being front-end and
rear-wheel drive, this has

never been a car to
just manhandle.
It's very accurate.

It feels much more like
a mid-engine car.

On the short-loop, which doesn't
matter here because

it's technical and it's quite
good for a fast road car.

So flat out, biggest news
is the gearbox.

The gearbox now shifts quickly,
and it is much more

responsive, much more
responsive.

You can really attack braking
zones, get on the brakes even
later, it feels.

And use the gearbox
to your advantage.

This car has always surprised
me with just how little
understeer it's got.
It's just fantastic.

Everyone of it as some great
big cruiser, and don't even

think of it as a genuine
458 but you have to.

It's that good to drum
up this engine.

OK, do I feel the extra
20 horsepower?

No, I don't, if I'm
honest with you.

But it is just a crackerjack
car.
Listen to that noise.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]
Down the back straight here.

Up into fifth, it is strolling
on, this thing.

Ah, it's a weapon,
it's a weapon.

They're doing a black
series of this.
What's that going to be like?

Traction control is a little
bit intrusive.

LED readouts here, they're
quite handy.

But it's strange, it drives
like a mid-engine car.
I just love these things.

It is the great unsung
car of the class.
Steering is fast.

Whole thing just feels like
a little racing car.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]
[TIRES SQUEAL]
And that engine.
[LAUGHS]

It seems to be pretty good
over the curves, as well.

Road cars don't like curves
This is a fantastic little
circuit, isn't it?
Technical, it's fast.

The GT's extra 20 horsepower
comes from calibration work,

specifically to fuel injection
timing and spark.

And the torque figure is the
same as the standard car's.

But that's still 479
foot-pounds.
A Ferrari 458.

By comparison, has
398 foot-pounds.

The chassis is subtly
differently too, with stiffer

springs, and a new adaptive
damping system.

It also uses new sticky
Dunlop rubber.

Inside GT means a bit redder,
red seat belts, stitching, and
just general extra redness.

It doesn't detract from the
fact, that the SLS is still a
very pleasant place to time.
[CAR ENGINE]

And if you turn the buttons
off, it will
get quite leery [LAUGHING]

It doesn't make much
sense financially.

And most people will think a
458 offers far more of what

they want from, a mere, 200,000
GBP super sports car.

But the SLS GT is subtly
different.

It's very competent on a
circuit, but it's actually
more of muscle car.

It burbles, and it rumbles, and
the doors are endlessly

enjoyable, and it's just a great
thing to spend time in.

Going fast or, crucially,
going slowly.

Is the GT package worth
the extra cash?
Well, probably not.

But if you're in for a penny,
you might as well be in for
the whole pound.

title: Mercedes SLS GT AMG: Hockenheim Track Test - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text:
depends on what you want. the aventador is faster and looks really crazy. 
But it's uncomfortable. Narrow inside and wide and hard to handle on the 
outside. It's very aggressive response could annoy you at some point. The 
SLS however looks more sophisticated and has better day to day value. It's 
not as fast and handles not as well, but the sound of the V8 is the best on 
the world! The gulllwing doors are funky and the car itself is a icon. You 
decide what to get

comments.text:
Chris Harris of DRIVE has driven just about every performance car in the 
world, so when he says the all-new SLS AMG GT is a genuine rival for 
anything meant to handle a track, he does so with some authority. But the 
real point comes across when Harris—red mist now descended—sums up the SLS 
GT as “just a crackerjack car” while clipping an apex at the 
Hockenheimring. 

Watch his full review here: http://youtu.be/cDjmN91UU4A﻿
comments.author: Olivier Veldkamp
